title: Epic: Milestone Gates and Vertical Slice Delivery
description:
Background:
PLAN.md defines M0-M8 gates. Team execution should map directly to those checkpoints.

Intent:
Create explicit milestone issues that depend on implementation outcomes to provide unambiguous readiness signals.

Scope:
M0-M8 acceptance gates with strict dependency wiring to underlying work items.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Epic dependencies close with demonstrable behavior, not just code presence.
- [ ] User-visible outcomes for this epic are validated in an end-to-end scenario.
- [ ] Operational considerations (testing/monitoring/docs) are captured before closure.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Rationale:
Milestone gates turn planning prose into binary execution checkpoints. This keeps progress measurable and prevents pseudo-completion.

Success signal:
Each milestone closes only when dependency-backed criteria are truly met.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Modeling decision:
We intentionally encoded hierarchy via dependencies (parent item depends on child work) instead of using --parent links, because br parent-child currently makes children depend on parent.

Convention for this backlog:
- Epics/tasks represent roll-up readiness by depending on implementation items.
- Subtasks are executable leaves that unblock parent tasks when closed.

Revisit if br parent semantics evolve.

title: Define canonical domain glossary, IDs, and invariants
description:
Background:
All downstream modules depend on stable identity semantics (agent_id, project_id, task_id, artifact_id, poi_id).

Work:
Define canonical naming/shape rules and invariants for each entity and relationship.

Deliverables:
- Shared model docs in repo
- Type definitions and schema validators
- Explicit invariants for lifecycle transitions

Outcome:
All later issues can depend on this issue as the baseline contract.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Canonical entity/ID glossary is published and referenced by protocol + scene schemas.
- [ ] Invariant list includes lifecycle transition guards for tasks, decisions, and artifacts.
- [ ] Validation rejects malformed IDs and illegal transition attempts in tests.
- [ ] At least one golden fixture validates end-to-end consistency of these IDs across message types.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Kickoff rationale:
This is the root contract issue for almost every implementation branch. Completing it first minimizes semantic drift and avoids expensive refactors across protocol, scene, and lifecycle models.

Practical outcome:
Once closed, downstream teams can execute in parallel with stable ID/entity semantics.

title: Epic: User Trust, Accessibility, and First-Run Experience
description:
Background:
The current backlog is technically comprehensive but under-specifies explicit user trust, accessibility, and first-run guidance.

Intent:
Ensure OfficeClaw feels understandable, controllable, and inclusive for real users during first contact and ongoing usage.

Scope:
- First-run onboarding and guidance
- Accessibility and reduced-motion accommodations
- Standardized empty/loading/error states
- Explainability and user control actions for agent behavior

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Epic dependencies close with demonstrable behavior, not just code presence.
- [ ] User-visible outcomes for this epic are validated in an end-to-end scenario.
- [ ] Operational considerations (testing/monitoring/docs) are captured before closure.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Why this revision was added:
User-facing clarity and trust mechanics are now explicit first-class work, not implicit assumptions hidden inside technical tasks.

Optimization goal:
Increase adoption and reduce confusion by making first-run guidance, accessibility, and explainability measurable deliverables.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Optimization revision:
Split planning from implementation so user-experience design work can progress immediately in plan-space (onboarding/a11y/content design) instead of waiting on UI implementation blockers.

title: Validate Meshy-generated desk GLB runtime load path before bulk generation
description:
Context:
User-directed spike generated prop_dev_desk via Meshy text-to-3d and replaced assets/glb/desk.glb for local preview. Runtime capture sessions show Scene Runtime loaded but overlay telemetry remains Startup assets: 0/0 loaded=0 failed=0, making in-game validation of generated GLB inconclusive.

Objective:
Debug and resolve runtime load/telemetry mismatch so generated GLBs can be reliably validated in-scene before mass Meshy generation for bd-9hcf.

Acceptance Criteria:
1. Repro path is documented with deterministic commands and artifact bundle.
2. Runtime session shows non-zero startup asset plan for cozy_office_v0 when assets are present (or clear documented reason if startup metric is deprecated).
3. Generated desk GLB from Meshy text-to-3d is verifiably loaded/rendered in game with screenshot evidence and no blocking runtime errors.
4. Findings + fix documented in a report with recommendation on whether to proceed with bulk generation.
close_reason: Resolved: startup telemetry bridge added to SceneRuntimeProvider; startup assets now reflect provider-managed loads (8/8 in cozy scene). Probe scene confirms Meshy text-to-3d desk GLB renders in-game. Evidence in reports/runtime-meshy-desk-validation.bd-28zr.md.

title: Client Polish Program: Offline-First Runtime Consolidation
description: Program-level epic for executing the full offline-first client polish roadmap in a way that is architecture-safe, reproducible, and backend-integration-ready. This epic exists to prevent partial local optimizations from reintroducing drift between scene authoring, runtime rendering, interaction routing, and offline command behavior.
acceptance_criteria:
1. All phase epics P0 through P9 are linked under this program and remain open until their deliverables are completed.
2. Dependency graph encodes critical sequencing and cross-phase handoffs for architecture, tooling, and QA.
3. Backlog content is self-contained enough for a new contributor to execute without prior chat context.
notes:
1. Program intent is to eliminate manifest-path drift, offline command dead ends, and duplicated runtime data paths.
2. Sequence intentionally prioritizes architecture and contract integrity before final visual polish.
3. QA and traceability artifacts are treated as first-class deliverables before freeze.
close_reason: Completed: program execution closed with NO-GO freeze outcome recorded in bd-2hik; follow-up requires new backlog items

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text: Updated acceptance criteria after backlog expansion so program-level completion signals reflect full dependency-encoded execution model.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Program context for future contributors:
1. This backlog is intentionally architecture-first: path and contract unification precede runtime migration, and runtime migration precedes visual pass.
2. The most important risk being mitigated is drift: duplicated manifest inputs, hardcoded interaction maps, and direct socket coupling in offline mode.
3. The dependency graph encodes the intended handoff chain so that readiness queues surface truly actionable work.
4. QA and traceability are treated as delivery artifacts, not cleanup tasks, because backend integration needs reproducible evidence and deterministic traces.
5. If scope pressure appears, defer optional demo enhancements before weakening contract and gateway milestones.

title: Epic: Contracts, Canonical Models, and Shared Types
description:
Background:
The repo currently defines behavior in docs (PLAN/PROTOCOL/SCENE_MANIFESTS/POI_AND_INTERACTIONS) but has no runtime code yet.

Intent:
Create one canonical source of truth for runtime data contracts so client/server/OpenClaw integration can be implemented without schema drift.

Scope:
- Domain model glossary and IDs
- Shared TypeScript schemas for protocol envelopes and payloads
- Versioning and compatibility rules
- Golden test fixtures for canonical flows

Non-goals:
- No UI polish or rendering work here
- No server runtime logic beyond schema validation scaffolding

Why this matters:
This epic reduces rework by locking down semantics before implementation and protects us from incompatible message formats across components.

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Epic dependencies close with demonstrable behavior, not just code presence.
- [ ] User-visible outcomes for this epic are validated in an end-to-end scenario.
- [ ] Operational considerations (testing/monitoring/docs) are captured before closure.

comments.author: HoangNB
comments.text:
Rationale:
We front-load contract clarity because this repo starts as docs-only. Shared schemas are the anti-drift mechanism that lets client/server/OpenClaw teams move in parallel without semantic mismatch.

Success signal:
Any message/manifest/lifecycle payload can be validated consistently across boundaries.

comments.author: HoangNB

title: Define protocol envelope and message schemas (hello/subscribe/event/snapshot/command/ack/error)
description:
Background:
PROTOCOL.md specifies a strict message envelope and message families.

Deliverables:
- Type-safe schema definitions for all message categories
- Runtime validation boundaries for inbound/outbound payloads
- Exhaustive enum sets for command names and error codes

Done when:
Schema coverage is complete and test fixtures compile against these definitions.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Schemas exist for all required message types in PROTOCOL.md sections 1-8.
- [ ] Envelope validation enforces type/id/ts/v/payload for every message.
- [ ] Invalid payload fixtures fail with deterministic error classes.
- [ ] Backward-compatible optional fields are supported without breaking existing fixtures.

title: P2-R Asset Provenance Recovery (Real Meshy Generation)
description: Recover Phase 2 asset production integrity by requiring live Meshy generation evidence, manifest artifacts, and provenance gates so placeholders/alias copies cannot satisfy completion.
acceptance_criteria:
1. Meshy credential setup and verification is documented and reproducible.
2. Required Phase 2 asset set is generated via live Meshy runs with per-asset manifests committed under reports/.
3. Asset provenance ledger maps each production GLB to Meshy manifest task IDs or explicit approved non-Meshy source.
4. Automated gate rejects placeholder/hash-reused assets for required production IDs.
5. Phase 2 closure packet cites manifest/provenance evidence and any exceptions.
notes: Kickoff started by HazyEagle. Immediate blocker chain: bd-dok7 requires MESHY_API_KEY for live auth verification; downstream generation tasks remain blocked until credentials are available.
close_reason: Completed: credential gate, env+agent live manifests, strict provenance pass, and reconciled closure packet all delivered (bd-dok7, bd-9hcf, bd-18j1, bd-2yns, bd-3eoj, bd-260p)
